head.title: Till the Cows (and Moose and Pigs) Come Home

hedline.hl1: Till the Cows (and Moose and Pigs) Come Home

abstract.p: Photo essay of outdoor art exhibits featuring whimsical statues of variety of animals and characters on view in Cincinnati, St Paul, Rhode Island, New York City and Toronto

block.p: In 1998, Zurich staged an outdoor exhibition of hundreds of fiberglass cows decorated by various artists, and Chicago did the same last summer. Each was a hit, and similar exhibitions are taking place in dozens of North American cities. Orlando, Fla., will be crawling with lizards; Grand Rapids, Mich., is a giant rabbit hutch; New Orleans is awash in fish, and St. Louis is sticking with two-leggers: people. Here are a few other examples.

In 1998, Zurich staged an outdoor exhibition of hundreds of fiberglass cows decorated by various artists, and Chicago did the same last summer. Each was a hit, and similar exhibitions are taking place in dozens of North American cities. Orlando, Fla., will be crawling with lizards; Grand Rapids, Mich., is a giant rabbit hutch; New Orleans is awash in fish, and St. Louis is sticking with two-leggers: people. Here are a few other examples.

Big Pig Gig, until Oct. 31. About 400 life-size fiberglass pigs in downtown Cincinnati, where live versions were herded through the streets in the mid-19th century. Also displayed in Covington and Newport, Ky.

The Birthplace of Fun, until Nov. 30. Over 50 six-foot-tall statues of Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head (created in 1952 in Pawtucket, R.I., by Hasbro), at attractions, restaurants and recreation areas statewide.
Moose in the City, through mid October. More than 250 life-size moose statues, mostly in downtown Toronto.
Peanuts on Parade, to early October. About 70 five-foot-tall statues of Snoopy (a creation of a native son, Charles M. Schulz), throughout the city.

CowParade New York 2000, until Sept. 3. Hundreds of life-size cows painted by artists and schoolchildren are on display at parks and other public spaces in the five boroughs. Stamford, Conn., and Orange, N.J., will also have exhibits.

TRAVEL ADVISORY Correction: July 2, 2000, Sunday A roundup of outdoor art shows on the Travel Advisory page last Sunday misidentified a New Jersey community that is having an exhibition of cow statues. It is West Orange, not Orange.
A roundup of outdoor art shows on the Travel Advisory page last Sunday misidentified a New Jersey community that is having an exhibition of cow statues. It is West Orange, not Orange.
